- 7 -
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
International Centre. Any assistance which the country might request from international sources in connexion with the epidemiological or public health aspect of the outbreak would be more appropriately provided through the WHO headquarters or regional staff than by the International Centres as these are at present constituted.
It must, however, be emphasized that while a National Centre would therefore appropriately look to the International Centre for assistance whenever necessary identifying or typing the causative organism of an outbreak, its own responsibilities in this particular connexion are nevertheless not to be minimized. An efficient National Centre will do practically all its own bacterial typing work, using diagnostic material which it has itself prepared with the help of standard materials provided by the International Centres, and it will send only special material to the International Centres. If National Centres were to send a high proportion of their material to the International Centre for identification this would throw quite an impossible load on the latter. It follows, therefore, that a measure of the real efficiency and economy of the working relationship between an International Centre and the National Centres is not so much the bulk of material sent in to and handled by the International Centre as the nature of this material.
許躍薾
CO-ORDINATION OF THE ACTIVITIES OF THE INTERNATIONAL CENTRES 140 112.213.82
(a) TECHNICAL FUNCTIONS
Since different groups of organisms are catered for by the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre on the one hand and the International Shigella Centres on the other, no serious danger of overlapping of functions - and therefore no significant problem of co-ordination - here arises. The salmonella materials normally supplied by the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre to a National Salmonella Centre on its initial contact with the latter are listed on table I (see pages 10 and 11). The escherichia materials supplied are listed on table II (see page 12).
In the work of the two International Shigella Centres, however, there is an obvious and considerable danger of duplication of effort, since the two centres deal with the same group of organisms. A programme of co-ordinated activity is therefore necessary, and a detailed programme of this nature follows:
國史饭 Academia Historica
